text: The Human Trafficking and Transportation Act (2007) aims to combat human trafficking and transportation offenses. The key provisions include: Definition: Human trafficking includes selling or purchasing a person for any purpose, engaging in prostitution, exploitation, or illegal transportation of people within and outside Nepal. Punishments: Severe penalties for traffickers, including long-term imprisonment and fines. Rehabilitation: Establishment of rehabilitation centers for victims. Victim Protection: Provision of safe shelters, legal aid, medical treatment, and rehabilitation for victims. Confidentiality: Protecting the privacy and identity of victims.

text: The Domestic Violence (Crime and Punishment) Act (2009) addresses violence within the home and aims to protect individuals from domestic abuse. text: Human Trafficking and Transportation (Control) Act, 2007: This Act prohibits all forms of human trafficking, including selling or buying a person, forced labor, sexual exploitation, organ removal, or illegal transportation. Victims are entitled to protection, rehabilitation, and compensation.

text: General Provisions on Citizenship in Nepal: Nepal provides a single federal citizenship with provincial (State) identity. No citizen may be deprived of the right to obtain citizenship. Citizenship is regulated by the Constitution and federal law. Applications are processed at District Administration Offices with required proofs such as birth certificates, parental citizenship documents, self-declarations, and other evidence. Denial or obstruction without lawful basis is punishable, with remedies available through courts.

text: Citizenship by Descent: A person acquires citizenship by descent if their father or mother (or both) was a Nepali citizen at the time of their birth. Children born in Nepal to Nepali parents qualify automatically. Recent 2025 amendments (operationalized 2026) allow issuance in the mother's name if the father's identity is unknown, untraceable, deceased, or disconnected (via self-declaration by mother and child, even if father's name appears on some documents but no other identity is available). This applies under 11(5) of the Constitution and amended Section 5 of the Citizenship Act.

text: Naturalized Citizenship: Granted in specific cases, including: (1) Foreign women married to Nepali citizens (upon request, after renouncing prior citizenship and meeting requirements). text: Non-Resident Nepali (NRN) Citizenship: Granted to foreign citizens of Nepali origin (who were previously Nepali citizens or whose parents/grandparents were Nepali by descent/birth and later acquired foreign citizenship, excluding SAARC countries in some restrictions). It provides economic, social, and cultural rights in Nepal (but excludes political and administrative rights). Eligibility: Former Nepali citizens who renounced citizenship or descendants of Nepali origin. Applications involve renunciation proof, foreign passport, and other documents; processed via Ministry of Foreign Affairs or designated offices. NRN status is governed by the Non-Resident Nepali Act, 2008, alongside citizenship provisions.

text: Summary of Types of Citizenship in Nepal: Nepal has a single federal citizenship with provincial (State) identity. The main types are: (1) Citizenship by Descent - Acquired automatically if the father or mother (or both) was a Nepali citizen at the time of birth; children born in Nepal to Nepali parents qualify, and 2025–2026 amendments allow issuance in the mother's name if the father's identity is unknown, untraceable, deceased, or disconnected (via self-declaration). (2) Citizenship by Birth - For persons born in Nepal before the 2015 Constitution commencement (if domiciled then) and their eligible descendants, who may convert to descent upon majority. (3) Naturalized Citizenship - Granted to: foreign women married to Nepali citizens (after renouncing prior citizenship); children born in Nepal to a Nepali mother and foreign father (if residing permanently and father untraceable); foreigners meeting residency (e.g., long-term), language, occupation, and other criteria; or those making special contributions (discretionary). (4) Honorary Citizenship - Awarded by the Government to foreign nationals in exceptional cases for outstanding merits or contributions. (5) Non-Resident Nepali (NRN) Citizenship - For former Nepali citizens or persons of Nepali origin who acquired foreign citizenship (excluding certain SAARC restrictions), providing economic, social, and cultural rights but excluding political and administrative rights. Applications for all types are handled by District Administration Offices (or Ministry of Home Affairs/Foreign Affairs for NRN/honorary), requiring documents like birth certificates, parental citizenship proof, marriage/renunciation certificates, self-declarations, etc. Denial of qualified citizenship is punishable, with legal remedies available.

text: Prenuptial Agreement in Nepal - Legal Recognition: Under Nepali law, prenuptial agreements (written contracts entered before marriage regarding property division or alimony upon divorce) are partially recognized. Section 102 of the National Civil (Code) Act, 2017 provides that, notwithstanding other provisions on divorce and property partition, if there is a written agreement between husband and wife on the partition share or alimony to which the wife is entitled upon divorce, the matter shall be decided according to that agreement. This allows couples to override default rules on property division in divorce cases, but the agreement must be voluntary, in writing, and not contrary to public policy or law.

text: Scope and Limitations of Prenuptial Agreements in Nepal: Prenuptial agreements in Nepal apply mainly to divorce scenarios, covering partition of marital property share and alimony (spousal maintenance) entitlements. They do not typically extend to events like death of a spouse (governed by succession laws), bankruptcy, or other marital changes. Agreements cannot violate fundamental rights, public morality, or statutory protections (e.g., rights of children or vulnerable parties). Courts may scrutinize for fairness, absence of duress/fraud, and full disclosure of assets. They are not as comprehensive or commonly practiced as in common-law countries, and full enforceability depends on judicial interpretation.

text: Enforceability of Prenuptial Agreements in Nepali Courts: A valid prenuptial agreement must be in writing, entered with free consent of both parties, and ideally notarized or registered for stronger proof. Courts will generally uphold it in divorce proceedings if it meets these criteria and does not contravene law or equity (e.g., no unfair deprivation of basic rights). However, prenups are not widely used or tested in Nepali jurisprudence, and some legal opinions view them as limited or interpretive. Parties are advised to consult family lawyers for drafting to maximize enforceability, especially for high-net-worth individuals or cross-border marriages.

text: Property Division and Alimony under Prenuptial Agreement: In the absence of a prenuptial agreement, marital property is divided according to default rules in the National Civil Code (e.g., equal or equitable share based on contribution, needs, and circumstances). With a valid agreement under Section 102, the court prioritizes the agreed terms on partition share and alimony upon divorce. This can protect pre-marital assets, business interests, or specify maintenance amounts, but cannot override child support obligations or basic spousal rights protected by law.

text: Postnuptial or Marital Property Agreements in Nepal: While prenuptial agreements (pre-marriage) receive limited statutory support under Section 102, postnuptial agreements (after marriage) or agreements on joint property management during marriage may also be recognized if in writing and consensual. These can address ongoing property rights, separation of assets, or future division, subject to the same principles of voluntariness, no coercion, and alignment with Civil Code provisions on marriage consequences and partition.

text: Overview of Starting a Business in Nepal: Nepal offers opportunities in sectors like tourism, hydropower, IT, agriculture, manufacturing, and services, but challenges include bureaucratic processes, infrastructure, and political stability. As of 2026, the process is largely online via the OCR's CAMIS portal (camis.ocr.gov.np). Key steps include choosing a business structure, reserving a name, preparing documents (e.g., MOA/AOA), online submission, fee payment, and post-registration compliances like PAN/VAT registration with Inland Revenue Department (IRD) and sector-specific licenses. Ease of doing business has improved with digital reforms, but foreign investors face minimum thresholds and approvals.
legal_document_source: Companies Act 2063 (2006, as amended) & Foreign Investment and Technology Transfer Act 2019

text: Types of Business Entities in Nepal: Common structures include: (1) Sole Proprietorship - Simplest, single owner with unlimited liability, registered with Department of Commerce/Industry or local offices. (2) Partnership Firm - 2+ partners sharing profits/losses, unlimited liability, registered under Partnership Act 2020 B.S. (3) Private Limited Company - Most popular for startups/SMEs, limited liability, separate legal entity, minimum 1 shareholder (up to 101), registered with Office of Company Registrar (OCR). (4) Public Limited Company - For larger businesses, can raise public capital, more compliance. Choose based on scale, liability, and funding needs.

text: Company Registration Process in Nepal (2026): Fully online via OCR CAMIS portal. Steps: (1) Create OCR account and reserve unique company name (English/Nepali). (2) Prepare documents: Application form, Memorandum of Association (MOA), Articles of Association (AOA), citizenship/passport copies of shareholders/directors, proposed objectives. (3) Submit online, pay fees based on authorized capital. (4) OCR reviews and issues Certificate of Incorporation (usually 7–15 days if complete). (5) Post-registration: Obtain PAN/VAT from IRD, open bank account, register for social security if employing staff. For foreign-owned companies, prior FDI approval from Department of Industry (DOI) required.

text: Foreign Direct Investment (FDI) and Business Setup in Nepal: Foreign investors can own up to 100% in most sectors (some restricted like retail trade, small agriculture). Minimum FDI threshold: NPR 20 million (~USD 150,000) per project. Process: (1) Apply for FDI approval from Department of Industry (DOI) for investments < NPR 6 billion, or Investment Board Nepal (IBN) for larger. (2) Submit project report, source of funds, shareholding details. (3) After approval, register company with OCR. (4) Remit funds via Nepal Rastra Bank (NRB). Benefits include repatriation of profits/dividends, technology transfer, and incentives in priority sectors (e.g., hydropower, IT). Some sectors now allow 100% foreign ownership post-2025 reforms.

text: Post-Registration Compliances for Businesses in Nepal: After incorporation, mandatory steps include: (1) Obtain Permanent Account Number (PAN) and VAT registration from Inland Revenue Department (IRD) if turnover exceeds thresholds. (2) Open corporate bank account and deposit share capital. (3) Register for Social Security Fund if employing 10+ staff. (4) Annual filings: Financial statements, audit reports (for companies), annual returns to OCR. (5) Sector-specific licenses (e.g., tourism from NTB, food from DFTQC). Non-compliance can lead to fines or deregistration. For foreign-owned entities, repatriation approvals via NRB required for dividends/profits.

text: Overview of Cyber Crime Laws in Nepal: The primary law governing cyber crimes is the Electronic Transactions Act, 2063 (2008), which criminalizes offenses related to unauthorized access, damage to computer systems, publication of illegal content, and breach of confidentiality in electronic records. It applies nationwide and extraterritorially if offenses affect Nepal. The National Penal (Criminal) Code Act, 2017 supplements with provisions on defamation, threats, privacy violations, and fraud via digital means. Cyber crimes have surged dramatically, with complaints rising from around 2,300 in FY 2019/20 to over 19,700 in FY 2023/24 and continuing upward trends into 2026, driven by social media misuse, financial fraud, and online harassment. Cases are handled by Nepal Police Cyber Bureau, with many reported via Hello Sarkar or online portals.

text: Unauthorized Access or Hacking: Accessing, using, or attempting to access any computer program, data, or information without authorization (or exceeding authorized access) is prohibited. This includes hacking into systems, networks, or devices. Punishment: Fine up to NPR 200,000 or imprisonment up to 3 years, or both, depending on severity (Section 45 of ETA). Additional penalties may apply under Penal Code for related fraud or damage.

This covers ransomware, malware deployment, or data destruction. Punishment: Imprisonment up to 3 years or fine up to NPR 200,000, or both (Section 44 and 46 of ETA).

text: Publishing or Transmitting Illegal/Obscene Content Online: Publishing, displaying, or transmitting obscene material, hate speech, defamation, threats, or content that humiliates/disrespects individuals (especially women) via electronic means is prohibited. This includes cyberbullying, deepfakes, morphed images, revenge porn, or inflammatory posts on social media. Punishment: Imprisonment up to 5 years or fine up to NPR 100,000–500,000, or both, depending on gravity (Sections 47–48 of ETA; cross-referenced with Penal Code Section 300 for threats/defamation).

This covers data leaks, doxxing, or unauthorized sharing of personal/financial info. Punishment: Fine up to NPR 10,000 or imprisonment up to 2 years, or both (Section 48 of ETA). Higher penalties may apply if linked to fraud or larger harm under Penal Code.

text: Online Fraud, Financial Crimes, and Related Cyber Conduct: Committing fraud, impersonation, phishing, or deception via electronic means (e.g., fake ads, bank scams, e-wallet fraud) is prohibited. This is covered under ETA for computer fraud and Penal Code for general cheating/forgery. Common in Nepal: social media scams, fake investment schemes, and extortion. Punishment: Varies; up to 3–5 years imprisonment and fines up to NPR 100,000–300,000 or twice the fraud amount (ETA Sections 45–47; Penal Code provisions on fraud). Victims can seek compensation and account blocking via Nepal Rastra Bank/Police.

text: Overview of Traffic Rules and Regulations in Nepal: Governed primarily by the Motor Vehicles and Transport Management Act, 2049 (as amended up to 2026), these rules apply to all vehicles on public roads. Key principles include safe driving, mandatory documents (license, bluebook/registration, insurance, fitness certificate), right-hand driving, speed limits (typically 40–80 km/h urban/highway), priority to pedestrians/crossings, and zero tolerance for drunk driving/mobile use. Recent 2026 amendments extend driving license validity to 10 years (from 5), introduce grace periods (3–7 days) for some fines, and propose stricter penalties for serious violations. Enforcement by Nepal Traffic Police; violations lead to fines, license suspension, vehicle impoundment, or court action.

text: Mandatory Safety Equipment and Rules: (1) Helmet compulsory for all two-wheeler riders (driver and pillion). (2) Seatbelt mandatory for front-seat passengers in four-wheelers (rear recommended). (3) No mobile phone use while driving (hands-free allowed in some cases but discouraged). (4) No overloading passengers/goods beyond capacity. (5) Valid third-party insurance required. Violation fines: No helmet/seatbelt NPR 1,000–1,500; mobile use NPR 1,000–3,000; overloading NPR 1,000–3,000. Repeated offenses may require traffic awareness classes.

text: Drink and Drive (Driving Under Influence): Strictly prohibited; any detectable alcohol (Ma Pa Se test) is an offense. Considered a major safety threat. Penalties: Fine NPR 1,000–10,000 (proposals for NPR 10,000+ in 2026 drafts), mandatory health check/counseling, license suspension (up to permanent revocation for repeats), possible imprisonment, and vehicle impoundment. text: Overview of Vehicle Registration in Nepal: Vehicle registration is mandatory for all motor vehicles (two-wheelers, cars, buses, trucks, etc.) to operate legally on public roads. Managed by the Department of Transport Management (DoTM) through zonal/provincial offices. It involves issuing a registration certificate (Bluebook), unique number plate (now mandatory embossed plates since September 2025/Ashoj 1, 2082), and linking to tax/insurance records. Process includes document submission, vehicle inspection, fee/tax payment, and issuance. Recent updates: Embossed plates required for new registrations, ownership transfers, and renewals; some services available via Nagarik App for viewing/paying taxes.

text: Required Documents for Vehicle Registration: Common documents include: (1) Application form (Form No. 1 or online equivalent). (2) Proof of identity (citizenship certificate, passport for foreigners). (3) Vehicle purchase invoice/bill of sale (from dealer or seller). (4) Customs clearance certificate (for imported vehicles). (5) Third-party insurance policy (mandatory). (6) Vehicle inspection/fitness report (technical check at DoTM). (7) Tax clearance/payment receipt (road tax, customs duty). (8) Entry registration (for imported vehicles). (9) Pollution/emission certificate. For embossed plates: Additional application via DoTM portal. Submit originals and copies; fees vary by vehicle type/engine capacity.

text: Step-by-Step Vehicle Registration Process (New/Private Vehicles): (1) Purchase vehicle and obtain invoice/insurance. (2) For imported vehicles: Complete customs clearance and entry registration at customs/police. (3) Visit local DoTM zonal office (e.g., in Bhadrapur for Koshi Province) or use online portal where available. (4) Submit application/documents and pay fees/taxes (road tax based on vehicle type/value). (5) Vehicle undergoes physical inspection (chassis/engine number verification, condition check). (6) If approved, receive temporary registration if needed, then final Bluebook and embossed number plate (mandatory since 2025). (7) Install embossed plate (via authorized vendors). Process typically takes 7–30 days; online elements via Nagarik App for tax viewing/payment.

text: Ownership Transfer (Used Vehicle Registration): Seller and buyer visit DoTM office together (or with authorization). Required: (1) Original Bluebook. (2) Tax clearance (no outstanding dues). (3) Application for transfer. (4) Identity proofs of both parties. (5) Purchase agreement/sale deed. (6) Insurance transfer. (7) Vehicle inspection if needed. Pay transfer fees/taxes. New owner receives updated Bluebook and retains same number plate (unless re-registration required). Embossed plate mandatory if not already installed. Process: 3–15 days; fines for non-transfer within time limit.

text: Overview of Vehicle Insurance Requirements in Nepal: Third-party liability insurance is compulsory for all motor vehicles (two-wheelers, cars, buses, trucks, etc.) as per the Motor Vehicles and Transport Management Act, 2049 (amended provisions). This covers legal liability for death, bodily injury, or property damage caused to third parties (other people/vehicles) by your vehicle. Driving without valid third-party insurance is illegal, leading to fines, vehicle impoundment, or license suspension. Comprehensive insurance (covering own vehicle damage, theft, fire, etc., plus third-party) is optional but recommended. Policies are issued by licensed insurers (e.g., Prabhu, Himalayan Everest, etc.), regulated by Beema Samiti. Insurance must be renewed annually or as per policy term, and proof is required for vehicle registration, Bluebook renewal, and road tax payment.

text: Mandatory Third-Party (Liability) Insurance: Every vehicle owner must obtain and maintain third-party liability insurance before registration or Bluebook renewal. It indemnifies the insured if legally liable for third-party damages (bodily injury, death, or property damage). Minimum coverage limits are set by Beema Samiti (e.g., NPR 10–50 lakh for death/injury, NPR 5–10 lakh for property, varying by vehicle type). Premiums are affordable (e.g., NPR 1,000–5,000 annually for two-wheelers/cars, higher for commercial vehicles). Proof of insurance is mandatory for DoTM services; non-compliance blocks registration/renewal and attracts fines (NPR 1,000–10,000+), penalties, or impoundment.

text: Comprehensive (Package) Insurance: Optional but widely chosen for full protection. Covers third-party liability plus own vehicle damage (accidents, theft, fire, natural disasters), passenger injury (for commercial vehicles), and optional add-ons (e.g., zero depreciation, roadside assistance). Not legally required but essential for financed vehicles (banks often mandate it). Premiums higher (e.g., 1–3% of vehicle value annually) based on make/model, age, location, and no-claim bonus. Claims must be reported within 24–72 hours; settlement timelines regulated under Insurance Act, 2079 (up to 30 days for valid claims).

text: Penalties for Non-Compliance with Insurance Requirements: Driving without valid third-party insurance is a serious offense. Penalties include fines (NPR 1,000–10,000+ depending on vehicle type/repeat offense), vehicle impoundment until insurance is obtained, license suspension, and potential criminal charges in accidents. For Bluebook renewal/registration, insurance proof is mandatory; expired policies block services. In accidents, uninsured drivers face full personal liability for third-party claims, plus legal consequences under the Act.

text: Applicability and Scope of Labor Act, 2074: The Labor Act, 2074 applies to all enterprises (companies, firms, cooperatives, associations, or organizations) in Nepal, regardless of size, profit motive, or number of employees. It covers all workers (permanent, contract, time-bound, part-time, casual) except certain exemptions like civil servants or domestic workers in private homes. The Act aims to promote fair industrial relations, prevent exploitation, ensure occupational safety, and provide social security. Foreign nationals require work permits from the Department of Labor. No headcount threshold exists (unlike older laws), making it universal for formal employment.

text: Employment Contracts and Types: Employers must execute written employment agreements (except casual employment) detailing job description, salary, working hours, leave, termination notice, and other terms. Types include: permanent (indefinite), time-bound/fixed-term (up to 5 years max, renewable), part-time, casual, and work-based. Contracts must be in Nepali or bilingual; verbal agreements are not valid for most purposes. Employers must provide a copy to employees and register with local Labor Office if required. Failure to provide written contract attracts penalties.

text: Working Hours, Overtime, and Rest: Standard working hours are 8 hours per day and 48 hours per week (6 days). Employees under 16 years limited to 6 hours/day and 36 hours/week. Overtime capped at 4 hours/day and 24 hours/week (increased from previous 20 hours); overtime pay is 1.5 times normal rate. Mandatory 30-minute break after 5 continuous hours. Weekly holiday (usually Saturday) and festival leave provided. Night shifts (10 PM–6 AM) require special consent and allowances. Violations lead to fines and back-pay orders.

text: Leave Entitlements: Employees are entitled to: (1) Annual paid leave (up to 18 days, accruable to 36 days max). (2) Sick leave (up to 12 days paid, accumulable). (3) Casual leave (12 days paid). (4) Festival leave (as per custom, up to 11–15 days). (5) Maternity leave (14 weeks/98 days total, minimum 60 days fully paid by employer; remaining via Social Security Fund if applicable). (6) Paternity leave (15 days paid). Additional unpaid leave possible on medical grounds or family emergencies. Employers must approve reasonable requests; denial without cause is punishable.

text: Minimum Wage and Remuneration: The government revises minimum wage every two years via the Minimum Wage Fixation Committee (Section 107). As of July 17, 2025 (effective Shrawan 1, 2082 BS), the national minimum monthly wage is NPR 19,550 (basic NPR 12,170 + dearness allowance NPR 7,380). Daily wage: NPR 752; hourly: NPR 89–107 (depending on category). Wages must be paid monthly without discrimination; overtime at 1.5x rate. Non-payment or underpayment attracts fines, back-wages, and penalties. Tea garden workers have separate rates.

text: Contribution-Based Social Security Fund (SSF): Mandatory for employers with 1+ employees (enrollment required since 2019). Employer contributes 20% of basic salary; employee 11% (total ~31%). Benefits include: medical/health/maternity protection (1%), accident/disability (1.4%), dependent family (0.27%), old-age pension (remaining). Contributions deposited monthly (within 15 days). Covers provident fund, gratuity, medical expenses, pensions. Non-compliance: fines up to NPR 500,000 + back contributions. SSF provides income security in old age, disability, or job loss.

text: Termination, Dismissal, and Dispute Resolution: Termination requires notice (30 days for permanent after probation) or payment in lieu. Just cause needed for dismissal (misconduct, poor performance); summary dismissal possible for grave offenses (theft, violence). Retrenchment (layoff) requires Labor Office approval and compensation (1 month salary per year served). Disputes resolved via Labor Court, Labor Offices, or mediation. Workers have right to appeal unfair termination. Reinstatement or compensation ordered if dismissal unlawful.

Just cause needed for dismissal (misconduct, poor performance); summary dismissal possible for grave offenses (theft, violence). Retrenchment (layoff) requires Labor Office approval and compensation (1 month salary per year served). Disputes resolved via Labor Court, Labor Offices, or mediation. text: Overview of Consumer Protection Act, 2075: The Consumer Protection Act, 2075 (2018) protects consumers' rights to safe, quality goods and services, fair pricing, accurate information, and redress for harm. It applies to all sellers, manufacturers, service providers, importers, and advertisers in Nepal (including e-commerce). Key consumer rights include protection from hazardous products, right to choose, right to be heard, right to compensation, and right to consumer education. The Act establishes Consumer Protection Councils, District Consumer Protection Committees, and Consumer Courts for complaints. Violations are punishable with fines up to NPR 500,000 and/or imprisonment up to 5 years, depending on severity.

text: Prohibition of Misleading Advertisement and False Claims: No person shall publish, broadcast, or display advertisements that are false, deceptive, exaggerated, or misleading about the quality, quantity, price, origin, benefits, or performance of goods/services. This includes fake discounts, unproven health claims, or hidden conditions. Punishment: Fine up to NPR 200,000 or imprisonment up to 1 year, or both (Section 16). The Department of Commerce can order withdrawal of such ads and impose additional penalties.

text: Right to Safe and Quality Goods/Services: Goods and services must be safe, of standard quality, and free from defects that could cause harm to health, property, or life. Sellers/manufacturers are liable for any damage caused by substandard or hazardous products. Consumers can demand replacement, repair, refund, or compensation. In case of injury/death, compensation may include medical expenses, loss of income, and moral damages. Punishment for selling unsafe goods: Fine up to NPR 500,000 or imprisonment up to 5 years, or both (Section 18).

text: Right to Fair Pricing and No Unfair Trade Practices: Sellers cannot charge prices higher than displayed/fixed rates, hoard goods to create artificial scarcity, or engage in unfair trade practices (e.g., price manipulation, black marketing, short-weighting). Consumers can complain about overcharging or defective weighing. Punishment: Fine up to NPR 100,000–500,000 or imprisonment up to 2 years, or both (Sections 22–24). District committees can seize goods and impose fines on the spot for minor violations.

text: Right to Information and Labeling Requirements: Every product must have clear, accurate labeling in Nepali (or bilingual) including name, ingredients, weight/quantity, manufacturing/expiry date, price, manufacturer/importer details, usage instructions, and warnings. No false or incomplete information allowed. Consumers have right to complete information before purchase. Violation: Fine up to NPR 100,000 or imprisonment up to 1 year, or both (Section 25). E-commerce platforms must display similar details.

text: Consumer Complaint and Redress Mechanism: Consumers can file complaints for defective goods, overcharging, unsafe services, or any violation at: (1) Local Ward Office or District Consumer Protection Committee (for minor issues), (2) Department of Commerce, Supplies and Consumer Protection (national level), or (3) Consumer Court (for higher-value claims). Complaints can be filed online via DoCSCP portal or helpline 1145. Redress includes refund, replacement, repair, or compensation. Time limit: 35 days from knowledge of defect/harm. Courts can award damages and litigation costs.

text: Product Liability and Compensation: Manufacturers, importers, sellers, and service providers are jointly and severally liable for harm caused by defective or substandard goods/services. Liability applies even without fault (strict liability for harm to life/health/property). Compensation covers medical expenses, loss of earnings, pain/suffering, and punitive damages in grave cases. In death cases, dependents can claim compensation. Penalties for causing serious harm/death: Imprisonment up to 5 years and fine up to NPR 500,000 (Section 20).

text: Overview of Environment Protection Act, 2076: The Environment Protection Act, 2076 (2019) is the principal law for environmental conservation, pollution prevention, sustainable development, and climate change adaptation in Nepal. It applies to all individuals, entities, projects, and government bodies. Key objectives include protecting the right to a clean and healthy environment (as a fundamental right under Constitution 30), preventing environmental degradation, and ensuring environmental impact assessment (EIA/IEE) for projects. The Act establishes the Ministry of Forests and Environment as the apex body, with provincial and local governments sharing implementation roles. Violations attract fines up to NPR 10 million and/or imprisonment up to 5 years.

text: Environmental Impact Assessment (EIA) and Initial Environmental Examination (IEE): Projects with potential significant environmental impact (listed in Schedule-1 of Rules) require full EIA; moderate-impact projects (Schedule-2) require IEE. EIA/IEE must be prepared by approved consultants, include public hearings, and be approved by the Ministry (EIA) or provincial/local authorities (IEE). No project can commence without approved EIA/IEE. Non-compliance: Project halt, fines NPR 500,000–10 million, and imprisonment up to 3 years (Section 29). EIA/IEE reports must be publicly disclosed.

text: Prohibition on Pollution and Emission Standards: No person or entity shall cause air, water, soil, or noise pollution beyond prescribed standards (set by the Ministry via notifications). Industries, vehicles, and construction must comply with emission limits, effluent standards, and noise thresholds. Polluters must install treatment plants and monitoring equipment. Penalty for pollution: Fine NPR 100,000–10 million or imprisonment up to 5 years, or both (Section 15). In case of serious harm (e.g., health damage, ecosystem loss), additional compensation and remediation orders apply.

text: Solid Waste Management and Hazardous Waste: Every person and entity must manage solid waste properly (segregation, collection, treatment, disposal). Local governments are responsible for municipal waste systems. Hazardous waste (chemicals, medical, industrial) requires special handling, licensing, and disposal at designated sites. Dumping or improper disposal prohibited. Penalty: Fine NPR 50,000–5 million or imprisonment up to 3 years, or both (Section 19). Extended Producer Responsibility (EPR) applies to certain products (e.g., batteries, plastics) since 2023 amendments.

text: Protection of Forests, Biodiversity, and Protected Areas: Cutting trees, encroaching forests, poaching, or damaging biodiversity without permit is prohibited. National parks, wildlife reserves, conservation areas, and buffer zones are strictly protected. Illegal trade in wildlife/forest products attracts severe penalties. Penalty for deforestation/encroachment: Fine NPR 100,000–10 million or imprisonment up to 5 years, or both (Section 25). Forest offenders may face additional community service or restoration orders.

text: Climate Change Adaptation and Mitigation: The Act mandates climate change integration into development plans, promotion of low-carbon technologies, and adaptation measures (e.g., disaster risk reduction). Polluters contributing to greenhouse gases face liability. Local governments must prepare climate vulnerability assessments. Penalty for non-compliance with climate-related standards: Fine NPR 200,000–5 million or imprisonment up to 3 years (Section 30). Nepal's National Adaptation Plan (2021–2050) and Climate Change Policy guide implementation.

text: Environmental Offenses, Penalties, and Compensation: Serious environmental damage (e.g., pollution causing death/injury, illegal mining, wildlife crime) triggers criminal liability. Fines range from NPR 50,000 to 10 million; imprisonment up to 5 years. Polluters must pay compensation for environmental restoration and victim harm (Section 32). Local communities can file complaints; public interest litigation allowed. Environmental offenders may face additional orders for remediation, license revocation, or project closure.

text: Overview of Intellectual Property Laws in Nepal: Nepal protects intellectual property through specialized statutes aligned with international treaties (Berne Convention, TRipS, Paris Convention, Madrid Protocol). Key laws include: Copyright Act, 2059 (literary/artistic works, software, databases); Patents, Designs and Trademarks Act, 2022 (patents, designs, trademarks); Geographical Indications Act, 2068 (GI products like Ilam tea, Darjeeling tea disputes, Janakpur Sita Rasgulla). Registration is handled by the Department of Industry (DoI) under the Ministry of Industry, Commerce and Supplies. Protection terms vary: copyright life + 50 years, trademarks 7 years (renewable), patents 7 years (renewable up to 21). Infringement is both civil (damages/injunction) and criminal (fines/imprisonment).
legal_document_source: Copyright Act, 2059 (2002); Patents, Designs and Trademarks Act, 2022; Geographical Indications Act, 2068

text: Copyright Protection and Registration: Copyright subsists automatically upon creation of original literary, artistic, musical, dramatic, cinematographic, photographic, sound recording, software, or broadcast works. Registration with DoI is optional but provides prima facie evidence in disputes. Protection duration: author's life + 50 years (corporate works 50 years from publication). Moral rights (attribution, integrity) protected perpetually. Fair use exceptions include private use, criticism, education, news reporting. Infringement (unauthorized reproduction, distribution, adaptation) punishable by fine NPR 100,000–500,000 or imprisonment up to 5 years, or both (Section 25).

text: Trademarks Registration and Protection: Trademarks (word, logo, slogan, shape, color combination) can be registered with DoI for 7 years, renewable indefinitely every 7 years. Nepal joined Madrid Protocol in 2019–2020, allowing international registration. Well-known marks protected even without registration. Infringement (unauthorized use causing confusion) leads to civil remedies (injunction, damages, account of profits) and criminal penalties: fine NPR 100,000–500,000 or imprisonment up to 1 year, or both (Section 18 of 2022 Act). Counterfeiting/seizure of goods common in enforcement.
legal_document_source: Patents, Designs and Trademarks Act, 2022, Sections 4–18

text: Patents Protection and Registration: Inventions that are new, involve inventive step, and are industrially applicable can be patented. Patent term: 7 years from filing, renewable twice (total 21 years). Application filed with DoI; examination required. No patent for discoveries, plants/animals (except microorganisms), methods of treatment, or inventions contrary to public order/morality. Infringement remedies: injunction, damages, seizure of infringing goods. Criminal penalty: fine NPR 200,000–1 million or imprisonment up to 2 years, or both. Compulsory licensing possible in public interest (e.g., health crises).

text: Industrial Designs Protection: New and original industrial designs (shape, configuration, pattern, ornamentation of articles) can be registered with DoI for 5 years, renewable twice (total 15 years). Protection prevents unauthorized copying or imitation. Infringement remedies: civil injunction/damages; criminal penalty: fine NPR 100,000–500,000 or imprisonment up to 1 year, or both. Common for furniture, textiles, packaging, consumer goods. No protection for functional aspects only.

text: Geographical Indications (GI) Protection: Geographical Indications identify goods originating from a specific region with unique quality/reputation (e.g., Ilam tea, Dhankuta oranges, Janakpur Sita Rasgulla). Registration with DoI prevents misuse. Unauthorized use of GI name punishable by fine NPR 100,000–500,000 or imprisonment up to 1 year, or both. Nepal has registered several GIs domestically and is pursuing international recognition. Protects traditional knowledge and rural economies.

text: Enforcement and Remedies for ip Infringement: ip owners can file civil suits in District Court for injunction, damages, accounts of profits, destruction of infringing goods, and costs. Criminal complaints filed with police for piracy/counterfeiting (seizure possible). Customs can seize infringing imports/exports on request. Nepal Police Cyber Bureau handles digital piracy. Enforcement challenges include slow courts, limited raids, and border issues, but recent campaigns target fake goods in markets and online platforms. Alternative: mediation or settlement encouraged.

text: Overview of Taxation System in Nepal: Nepal's taxation system is governed by direct taxes (Income Tax Act, 2058) and indirect taxes (VAT Act, 2052; Excise Duty Act, 2058). The Inland Revenue Department (IRD) administers income tax, VAT, excise, customs duties (via Customs Act), and other levies. Key principles: progressive taxation, residency-based taxation (resident individuals/companies taxed on worldwide income), source-based for non-residents. Major taxes include personal/corporate income tax, VAT (13% standard rate), excise on luxury goods, and customs duties. Digital filing mandatory via IRD portal (ird.gov.np) for most taxpayers; PAN compulsory for businesses and high-income individuals. Tax year: Shrawan 1 to Ashad end (mid-July to mid-July).
legal_document_source: Income Tax Act, 2058 (as amended); Value Added Tax Act, 2052; Excise Duty Act, 2058

text: Personal Income Tax (Individuals): Residents taxed on worldwide income; non-residents on Nepal-sourced income. Tax slabs for FY 2082/83 (2025/26): Up to NPR 500,000 – 1%; NPR 500,001–700,000 – 10%; NPR 700,001–1,000,000 – 20%; NPR 1,000,001–2,000,000 – 30%; above NPR 2,000,000 – 36% (plus 20% additional tax on income above NPR 5 million for high earners in some cases). Basic exemption NPR 500,000 (individuals), NPR 600,000 (couples filing jointly), plus additional exemptions for women, seniors, disabled. Social security contributions deductible. Filing deadline: Ashoj end (mid-October). Non-filing attracts penalties and interest.

text: Corporate Income Tax: Resident companies taxed at 25% on net taxable income (worldwide). Banks/financial institutions 30%; life/non-life insurance 25–30%; small/micro industries 20% (if turnover < NPR 50 million). Foreign companies with permanent establishment in Nepal taxed at 25% on Nepal-sourced income. Deductions allowed for business expenses, depreciation, interest, bad debts, R&D. Withholding tax on dividends (5%), interest (15%), royalties (15%), service fees to non-residents (15%). Tax incentives for priority sectors (hydropower, IT, agriculture). Filing deadline: 3 months after fiscal year-end.

text: Value Added Tax (VAT): VAT is a 13% indirect tax on most goods and services (standard rate). Registration mandatory if annual turnover exceeds NPR 5 million (goods) or NPR 2 million (services). Zero-rated items include exports, basic agriculture products, education/medical services. Exempt items: basic food grains, medicine, books. Input tax credit allowed for registered businesses. Monthly/quarterly returns and payments required. Non-compliance: fines NPR 10,000–100,000 + interest (15% per annum) + penalty up to 100% of tax due. E-invoicing mandatory for many sectors since 2024.
legal_document_source: Value Added Tax Act, 2052 (as amended) & VAT Rules

text: Excise Duty and Customs Duties: Excise duty levied on luxury/imported goods (e.g., alcohol, tobacco, vehicles, petroleum products) at rates set annually (e.g., 10–200% on certain items). Customs duties (via Customs Act) range from 0–80% on imports, with reduced rates under SAFTA, WTO, and bilateral agreements. Export duties minimal. VAT + excise applicable on imports. Non-payment or evasion: fines up to 3 times duty + imprisonment up to 5 years. Customs can seize goods; appeals to Revenue Tribunal.
legal_document_source: Excise Duty Act, 2058 & Customs Act, 2064 (as amended)

text: Tax Filing, Payment, and Compliance: All taxpayers must obtain PAN from IRD. Annual income tax returns due by Ashoj end (mid-October) for individuals; within 3 months of fiscal year-end for companies. Advance tax payments quarterly for businesses. VAT/excise returns monthly or quarterly. E-filing mandatory via IRD portal (ird.gov.np); digital signatures accepted. Late filing attracts 0.1% per day interest + penalties (10–50% of tax due). Audits mandatory for large taxpayers; voluntary disclosure schemes offered periodically.
legal_document_source: Income Tax Act, 2058, Sections 94–100 & IRD directives 2025–2026

text: Tax Offenses, Penalties, and Evasion: Tax evasion, under-reporting, false returns, or non-filing are serious offenses. Penalties: 50–200% additional tax + interest (15% p.a.) + fines. Willful evasion: imprisonment up to 3–5 years + fine up to NPR 1 million (Section 117 of Income Tax Act). Fraudulent claims/refunds attract higher penalties. IRD can issue demand notices, freeze bank accounts, seize property. Amnesty schemes occasionally offered for voluntary disclosure. Anti-evasion measures include data matching with banks, customs, and third-party reporting.

text: Overview of Banking Regulations in Nepal: Nepal Rastra Bank (NRB), established under the Nepal Rastra Bank Act, 2058 (2002), is the central bank responsible for licensing, regulating, supervising, and inspecting banks and financial institutions (BFIs). The Banks and Financial Institutions Act, 2073 (BAFIA 2017, as amended) consolidates laws on establishment, operation, governance, mergers, and resolution of BFIs. BFIs are classified into Class A (commercial banks), B (development banks), C (finance companies), and D (microfinance). NRB issues Unified Directives annually (latest: Unified Directives 2082 for FY 2082/83, effective 2026), covering credit, risk management, AML/CFT, corporate governance, and foreign exchange. Recent reforms include easing outward investment, removing single obligor limits for large projects, and D-SIB framework for systemic banks.
legal_document_source: Banks and Financial Institutions Act, 2073 (as amended); Nepal Rastra Bank Act, 2058; Unified Directives 2082 (2026)

text: Licensing and Classification of Banks and Financial Institutions: NRB issues licenses to BFIs based on minimum paid-up capital, proposed operations, and area (Class A: nationwide commercial; B: development-focused; C: finance; D: microfinance). Minimum capital requirements vary (e.g., Class A: NPR 8–10 billion in 2026). Applications require feasibility study, promoter details, and fit-and-proper tests for directors/management. NRB can reject or impose conditions. Unauthorized banking operations punishable by fines up to NPR 10 million and/or imprisonment up to 5 years (BAFIA Section 49). Mergers/acquisitions require prior NRB approval.
legal_document_source: Banks and Financial Institutions Act, 2073, Sections 33–37 & Unified Directives 2082

text: Corporate Governance and Risk Management: BFIs must have independent boards (minimum 5–7 directors, with independent and woman directors required), audit/risk committees, and fit-and-proper criteria for CEOs/directors. NRB mandates internal controls, credit risk assessment, AML/CFT policies, and stress testing. Unified Directives 2082 emphasize loan classification/provisioning, single borrower exposure limits (relaxed for large projects), and related-party lending restrictions. Non-compliance: fines NPR 1–10 million, director disqualification, or license suspension/revocation (BAFIA Sections 46–50).

text: Credit and Lending Regulations: BFIs must follow prudential norms on loan classification (pass, watchlist, substandard, doubtful, loss), provisioning (1–100%), and exposure limits. Unified Directives 2082 removed strict single obligor limits for infrastructure/large projects (board-approved risk policies suffice) and eased margin lending lock-ins (now 6 months). Loan-to-value (LTV) ratios tightened for housing (up to 80% for first-time buyers). Non-performing loans monitored closely; high NPLs trigger corrective actions. Violations: fines, restrictions on dividends, or management changes.

text: Anti-Money Laundering and Countering Financing of Terrorism (AML/CFT): BFIs must implement KYC/CDD, monitor transactions, report suspicious activities to Financial Intelligence Unit (FIU-Nepal under NRB), and maintain records for 5 years. NRB's AML Directives (updated 2082) require risk-based approach, customer due diligence, and training. Cash transaction limits (e.g., NPR 500,000+ must be non-cash from January 2026) aim to curb black money. Penalties for non-compliance: fines up to NPR 10 million, license suspension, or criminal prosecution (up to 5 years imprisonment under Asset (Money) Laundering Prevention Act).
legal_document_source: Asset (Money) Laundering Prevention Act, 2064 (as amended) & NRB AML Directives 2082

text: Foreign Exchange and Outward Investment Regulations: NRB regulates forex transactions, capital inflows/outflows, and repatriation. Residents can invest abroad in limited sectors (e.g., IT, hydropower) under recent amendments (Foreign Investment and Loan Management Bylaws, fifth amendment 2025). Repatriation of dividends/profits allowed after tax clearance. Banks must report forex dealings. Violations (illegal forex trading): fines up to NPR 5 million + imprisonment up to 3 years. NRB issues swap/NDF regulations for hedging and eases equity inflows.

text: Banking Offenses, Penalties, and Blacklisting: Offenses include unauthorized banking, cheque bounce, loan fraud, insider lending, and non-compliance with directives. Penalties: fines NPR 1–10 million, imprisonment up to 5 years, license revocation, and blacklisting (barring access to credit for up to 10 years). Blacklisted borrowers can appeal to NRB or settle dues for removal. NRB can issue corrective orders, restrict dividends, or supersede boards for weak governance. Recent focus on loan monitoring (income verification via tax filings) and D-SIB supervision for systemic stability.

text: Overview of Land Law in Nepal: The Land Act, 2021 B.S. (1964, as amended up to 2026) is the principal law governing land ownership, tenure, ceilings, tenancy, acquisition, and registration. It classifies land as private (raiyati), public (sarkari), guthi, forest, and government-owned. Private land can be owned, transferred, mortgaged, and inherited, subject to ceilings and restrictions on fragmentation. Land registration is mandatory for ownership transfer (via Land Revenue Office). Recent amendments focus on digitization (e-Land records), women's inheritance rights, and land acquisition for public projects with fair compensation.

text: Land Ownership and Registration Process: Ownership is proven by registration certificate (Lalpurja) issued by Land Revenue Office after mutation (name transfer). Registration required for sale, gift, partition, inheritance. Documents: citizenship, sale deed, tax clearance, previous Lalpurja. Process: submit application, pay fees (1–5% of land value as registration fee + stamp duty), survey verification if needed, and receive updated Lalpurja. Digital records (e-Land) mandatory in many districts since 2024–2025. Unregistered transfers invalid against third parties.
legal_document_source: Land Act, 2021 B.S. (Sections 3–10) & Land Revenue Act

text: Land Ceiling and Fragmentation Restrictions: Land ceiling limits apply: 25 ropani (Terai), 10 ropani (hills), 5 ropani (Kathmandu Valley) for agricultural land per family. Excess land acquired by government with compensation. Minimum parcel size for transfer: 0.5 ropani (Terai), 0.25 ropani (hills) to prevent fragmentation. Exemptions for family partition, inheritance, and certain commercial uses. Violation: excess land confiscated without compensation; fines NPR 50,000–500,000.

text: Tenancy Rights and Tenant Protection: Tenants (mohi) cultivating land for 3+ years acquire tenancy rights (up to 50% share of produce). Tenancy heritable but non-transferable without landlord consent. Eviction only for non-payment of rent, misuse, or landlord's personal cultivation need (with notice and compensation). Recent amendments strengthen tenant rights and digitize tenancy records. Disputes resolved at Land Revenue Office or District Court. Illegal eviction: fines NPR 100,000–1 million + reinstatement.

text: Land Acquisition for Public Purpose: Government can acquire private land for public projects (infrastructure, hydropower, schools) with fair compensation (market value + 10–30% solatium + relocation costs). Process: notification, EIA/IEE, public hearing, valuation by committee, payment within 6 months. Landowners can appeal valuation to District Court. Recent 2025–2026 amendments emphasize prompt payment and rehabilitation for displaced families. Non-compliance: project halt, fines NPR 500,000–5 million.
legal_document_source: Land Acquisition Act, 2034 & Land Act, 2021 B.S. (amended provisions)

text: Land Survey, Measurement, and Boundary Disputes: Land survey conducted by Survey Department (Survey Act, 1969). Boundary disputes resolved by local Land Revenue Office with field verification and neighbor testimony. Adverse possession possible after 12 years continuous possession (good faith). Digital cadastral maps expanding since 2020. Illegal encroachment on public/government land: eviction + fines NPR 50,000–1 million + imprisonment up to 1 year. Forgery of land documents: criminal penalties under Penal Code.

text: Women's Inheritance and Land Rights: Women have equal inheritance rights to ancestral property (since 2002 amendment, reinforced 2015 Constitution 38). Daughters inherit equally with sons. Married daughters retain rights unless relinquished. Land registration in woman's name encouraged (some tax incentives). Disputes resolved in family partition or court. Denial of women's land rights punishable under civil/criminal provisions (fines NPR 50,000–500,000 + compensation).

text: Overview of Public Health and Medical Law in Nepal: The Public Health Act, 2075 (2018) is the main law governing public health services, disease prevention, health facilities, medical professionals, and emergency response. It establishes the Ministry of Health and Population as the apex body, with provincial and local governments delivering services. Key areas: right to basic health services (Constitution 35), licensing of health institutions/professionals, epidemic control, food/drug safety (via DFTQC), and medical negligence. Violations attract fines NPR 50,000–5 million and/or imprisonment up to 3 years.
legal_document_source: Public Health Act, 2075 (2018) & Health Services Act, 2053

text: Right to Health Services and Free Basic Care: Every citizen has the right to basic health services free of cost (Constitution 35). Public Health Act mandates free essential medicines, emergency care, maternal/child health, immunization, and treatment for communicable diseases (e.g., TB, HIV, leprosy). Government reimburses private facilities for certain services. Denial of emergency treatment punishable by fines NPR 100,000–1 million + license suspension (Section 10).

text: Licensing of Health Professionals and Institutions: Doctors, nurses, pharmacists, and other health workers must register with Nepal Medical Council, Nepal Nursing Council, or respective councils. Private hospitals, clinics, pharmacies, and labs require licenses from provincial/local authorities. Minimum standards for infrastructure, staffing, equipment mandated. Unlicensed practice: fines NPR 200,000–2 million + imprisonment up to 2 years + closure (Section 20). Fake degrees or quackery attract harsher penalties.

text: Medical Negligence and Patient Rights: Health professionals must provide standard care; negligence (wrong diagnosis, surgical error, lack of consent) punishable. Patients have right to informed consent, confidentiality, second opinion, and compensation. Medical negligence cases filed in Consumer Court or civil court. Compensation up to NPR 5 million possible; criminal liability (imprisonment up to 3 years) if gross negligence causes death/harm (Section 30). Hospitals must maintain records and report adverse events.

text: Epidemic and Public Health Emergency Control: Government can declare epidemics/public health emergencies, impose quarantines, lockdowns, mandatory vaccination, and restrict movement. Non-compliance (e.g., hiding symptoms, violating quarantine) punishable by fines NPR 50,000–500,000 + imprisonment up to 1 year. Health facilities must report notifiable diseases. Recent amendments strengthen coordination with provincial/local levels post-COVID.

text: Food and Drug Safety Regulation: Food/drug quality controlled by Department of Food Technology and Quality Control (DFTQC) under Public Health Act. Adulterated/spurious food/drugs prohibited. Labeling, expiry, standards mandatory. Violations: fines NPR 100,000–5 million + imprisonment up to 5 years + product seizure/destruction. Drug pricing regulated; overcharging punishable. Pharmacies must have licensed pharmacists.

text: Organ Transplantation and Related Offenses: Regulated under Human Body Organ Transplantation Act (and Penal Code provisions). Donation must be voluntary; commercial trade prohibited. Living donors limited to close relatives; brain-dead donations allowed. Unauthorized removal/sale: imprisonment up to 10 years + fine. Hospitals must be licensed for transplants. Violations (organ trafficking) attract severe penalties under human trafficking laws.

text: Overview of Education Law in Nepal: The Education Act, 2028 B.S. (1971, as amended) and ongoing School Education Bill (passed in principle 2025, expected full enactment 2026) govern school education. Constitutional right to free and compulsory basic education (31). Structure: pre-primary, basic (1–8), secondary (9–12). Ministry of Education, Science and Technology (MoEST) sets policy; provincial/local governments manage schools. Key principles: equitable access, quality standards, teacher licensing, curriculum uniformity. Violations (e.g., unauthorized schools) attract fines NPR 50,000–1 million + closure.
legal_document_source: Education Act, 2028 B.S. (as amended) & School Education Bill (2025–2026)

text: Free and Compulsory Basic Education: Basic education (grades 1–8) is free and compulsory for children aged 5–14. Government provides free textbooks, scholarships for marginalized groups, and midday meals in many schools. Parents/guardians must enroll children; non-compliance can lead to counseling or fines (rarely enforced). Private schools must follow national curriculum and fee regulation guidelines. Denial of admission on caste/gender grounds punishable.

Minimum standards: infrastructure, qualified teachers, sanitation, safety. Private schools must be registered as companies or trusts and follow fee ceilings (regulated by local committees). text: Overview of Reservation System in Nepal: The Constitution of Nepal, 2015 mandates proportional inclusion and positive discrimination for women, Dalits, indigenous nationalities (Janajati/Adivasi), Madhesi, Tharu, Muslims, persons with disabilities, and citizens from backward regions. Reservation applies in public employment (civil service), education (scholarships, seats), political representation (federal/provincial/local assemblies), and public bodies. The system aims to correct historical discrimination and ensure equitable participation. Quotas are implemented through the Public Service Commission (for jobs), universities/UGC (education), and Election Commission (politics). Non-compliance by public entities attracts legal challenges and penalties.

text: Reservation in Public Employment (Civil Service): In civil service recruitment (via Public Service Commission), reservation quota is 45% of total posts: 33% women (horizontal), 9% Dalit, 15% indigenous nationalities (Janajati), 12% Madhesi, 5% Tharu, 2% Muslims, 2% persons with disabilities, 3% backward regions (vertical). Remaining 55% open competition. Within reserved categories, women get priority. Quota applies to gazetted and non-gazetted posts. Merit-based within quota; no reservation in promotion (except some special provisions). Violation or misuse: PSC can cancel results; legal action possible.

text: Overview of Federal Parliament in Nepal: The Federal Parliament is the supreme legislative body of Nepal, consisting of two houses: the House of Representatives (Pratinidhi Sabha - lower house) and the National Assembly (Rastriya Sabha - upper house). It exercises federal legislative powers, makes laws, approves budgets, oversees the executive, ratifies treaties, and amends the Constitution. The Parliament meets in Kathmandu at the Federal Parliament Building. Sessions are summoned/prorogued by the President on the recommendation of the Prime Minister. The Constitution (Articles 83–111) defines its structure, powers, privileges, and procedures.

text: House of Representatives (Pratinidhi Sabha) - Lower House: The House of Representatives is the directly elected lower house with 275 members: 165 elected by first-past-the-post (FPTP) in single-member constituencies and 110 elected through proportional representation (PR) nationwide. Term: 5 years (unless dissolved earlier). Presided over by the Speaker (elected from among members). It is the primary legislative body, initiates money bills, can form/remove governments (confidence/no-confidence motions), and has greater powers in financial and executive accountability matters. Quorum: one-fourth of total members.

text: National Assembly (Rastriya Sabha) - Upper House: The National Assembly is the indirectly elected upper house with 59 members: 8 appointed by the President on government recommendation, 3 nominated by the President (experts), and 56 elected by an electoral college (provincial assembly members + local level heads/vice-heads) using single transferable vote (STV). Term: 6 years (1/3 members retire every 2 years for continuity). Presided over by the Chairperson. It reviews, amends, and delays bills passed by the House of Representatives (except money bills) and represents provinces and marginalized groups.

text: Legislative Powers and Bill-Passing Process: Both houses share legislative powers (ordinary bills can originate in either house). Money bills (taxes, loans, budget) can only originate in the House of Representatives and must be certified as such by the Speaker; National Assembly can only suggest amendments (within 15 days) which the lower house may accept or reject. Ordinary bills require passage by both houses; in case of disagreement, a joint committee resolves it. Constitutional amendment bills require two-thirds majority in both houses.

text: Parliamentary Committees and Oversight: Both houses form committees (e.g., Finance, Public Accounts, State Affairs, Sustainable Development) for detailed scrutiny of bills, budgets, and government actions. Committees can summon ministers/officials, conduct inquiries, and recommend actions. Public Accounts Committee (chaired by opposition MP) audits government expenditure. Committees have powers of a court for summoning witnesses and documents. Non-compliance with committee summons punishable as contempt of Parliament.

text: Parliamentary Privileges and Immunities: Members of Parliament enjoy freedom of speech and vote in the house (no liability for anything said or voted). They cannot be arrested during sessions (except for serious crimes) and enjoy immunity from civil/criminal proceedings for acts in Parliament. Contempt of Parliament (disrespecting house/committee) punishable by imprisonment up to 6 months or fine. Privileges extend to committees and joint sittings. Misuse of privileges can lead to disciplinary action by the house.

text: Joint Sittings and Special Provisions: Joint sittings of both houses are summoned by the President for specific purposes (e.g., President's address, constitutional amendment bills requiring two-thirds majority). In joint sittings, decisions are by majority vote (Speaker presides). In case of deadlock on ordinary bills, a joint committee resolves differences. No joint sitting for money bills or impeachment proceedings. Emergency provisions can extend Parliament's term during national crises.

text: Overview of Emergency Provisions in Nepal: The Constitution of Nepal, 2015 (273) allows the President, on the recommendation of the Council of Ministers, to proclaim a state of national emergency if the sovereignty, territorial integrity, or security of Nepal is threatened by war, external aggression, armed rebellion, or serious natural disaster. Emergency powers suspend certain fundamental rights (except life, dignity, fair trial, torture prohibition, and others listed in 274). Proclamation must be approved by a two-thirds majority in the House of Representatives within one month and can last up to six months (extendable). Nepal has never declared full martial law; the closest was the 2005 royal emergency under the 1990 Constitution.

text: Proclamation and Approval of National Emergency: The President proclaims a national emergency only on the written recommendation of the Council of Ministers (headed by the Prime Minister). The proclamation must be laid before the House of Representatives within one month and approved by a two-thirds majority of members present and voting. If the House is dissolved or not in session, approval must occur within 30 days of its first meeting after proclamation. Emergency ends automatically if not approved or if the House passes a resolution to end it. Extension beyond six months requires fresh approval every six months.

text: Powers During National Emergency: During a proclaimed emergency, the executive can issue ordinances having the force of law (if Parliament is not in session), suspend enforcement of certain fundamental rights (except Articles 16–19, 23–25, 29–31), deploy Nepal Army if needed (on Council of Ministers' recommendation), and take measures to protect sovereignty/security. The President can dissolve the House of Representatives only on Prime Minister's advice, but emergency does not automatically dissolve Parliament. All emergency actions must be laid before Parliament for approval.

text: No Martial Law Provision in Nepal: The Constitution of Nepal does not provide for or use the term 'martial law'. Emergency powers are civilian-led (Council of Ministers recommends, President proclaims, Parliament approves). Deployment of Nepal Army during emergency is possible but remains under civilian control (267). Historical attempts to impose military rule (e.g., 2005 royal takeover) were declared unconstitutional by the Supreme Court in 2006. Any attempt to impose martial law would violate the Constitution and be subject to judicial review.

text: Interim Government / Caretaker Government: When the House of Representatives is dissolved or no government can be formed (e.g., after no-confidence vote or resignation), the President appoints a caretaker/interim government headed by the outgoing Prime Minister or a senior leader. Its role is limited to day-to-day administration, routine duties, and conducting elections within six months. It cannot make major policy decisions, enter long-term commitments, or dissolve the House again. Caretaker governments have operated in Nepal (e.g., 2021, 2024) under Supreme Court guidance.

text: Power Vacuum and Constitutional Succession: Nepal's Constitution provides clear succession to avoid power vacuum: (1) Prime Minister resigns/removal → President appoints new PM (majority leader, coalition, or largest party). (2) If no PM can be appointed → President can dissolve House and order elections within six months (85). (3) President acts on Council of Ministers' advice (even caretaker). (4) In extreme cases (e.g., dissolution without PM advice), Supreme Court can intervene (as in 2020–2021 cases). No power vacuum has occurred post-2015 Constitution due to these mechanisms.

text: Judicial Review and Safeguards Against Emergency Abuse: All emergency proclamations, ordinances, and actions during emergency are subject to judicial review by the Supreme Court. The Court can declare emergency provisions unconstitutional if they violate non-derogable rights or exceed necessity. Historical precedent: 2005 royal emergency declared unconstitutional in 2006. Emergency cannot suspend judicial review, habeas corpus (except temporarily), or fundamental rights to life/dignity/fair trial. Citizens can file writ petitions during emergency to challenge violations.

text: Overview of Muslim Personal Law in Nepal: Nepal does not have a separate codified Muslim Personal Law or Sharia courts. All citizens, including Muslims, are subject to the uniform Muluki Civil (Code) Act, 2074 (2017) for marriage, divorce, polygamy, maintenance, and inheritance. The Constitution (18) guarantees equality before law and prohibits discrimination on grounds of religion. Limited customary practices of Muslims are tolerated only if they do not violate fundamental rights or national law. Polygamy is completely banned for everyone, including Muslims, with no religious exemption.

text: Prohibition of Polygamy for All Citizens Including Muslims: Section 173 of the Muluki Civil (Code) Act, 2074 explicitly prohibits polygamy (multiple simultaneous marriages). A person who marries again while their first marriage is subsisting commits an offense. This applies uniformly to all religious communities, including Muslims. No religious exemption exists for polygamy under Nepali law. Punishment: imprisonment up to 3 years and/or fine up to NPR 10,000. The second marriage is void ab initio.

text: Legal Status of Multiple Wives Under Nepali Law: A Muslim man cannot legally have more than one wife at a time in Nepal. Any second or subsequent marriage during the subsistence of the first is illegal and void. The first wife can file for divorce or seek maintenance/compensation. Children from the second (void) marriage are considered legitimate for inheritance purposes under Section 205 of the Civil Code (presumption of legitimacy), but the second wife has no legal marital rights. Courts consistently uphold monogamy as a matter of public policy and equality.

text: Marriage Registration Requirement for Muslims: All marriages, including those performed under Muslim rites (nikah), must be registered at the ward office or concerned authority within 15 days (Section 67 of Muluki Civil Code). Unregistered marriages are not legally recognized for inheritance, maintenance, or other civil rights. Muslim marriages must also comply with monogamy rule. Bigamy complaints can be filed by the first spouse or any affected party, leading to criminal prosecution under Section 173.

text: Divorce and Maintenance Rights in Muslim Marriages: Divorce (talaq, khula, mubara'at) is recognized if registered and compliant with national law. Triple talaq (instant oral divorce) is not automatically valid; it must follow due process and registration. The first wife has full right to maintenance, dower (mahr), and share in property. A second (illegal) wife has no legal claim to maintenance or inheritance from the husband. Courts may award compensation to the aggrieved wife in bigamy cases.

text: Legal Consequences and Enforcement Against Polygamy: Bigamy (second marriage while first subsists) is a criminal offense under Section 173 of the Civil Code. The aggrieved spouse (usually first wife) or any person can file a complaint in District Court. Punishment: up to 3 years imprisonment and/or NPR 10,000 fine. The second marriage is declared void. Courts have consistently refused to recognize religious justifications for polygamy, upholding monogamy as a constitutional principle of equality (18). Cases are prosecuted under general criminal law.

text: Overview of Domestic Violence Law in Nepal: The Domestic Violence (Crime and Punishment) Act, 2066 (2009) criminalizes any act of physical, mental, sexual, or economic abuse committed by a family member (including spouse) against another family member. The law is gender-neutral — it applies equally to violence by husband against wife and by wife against husband. Punishment includes imprisonment (up to 6 months), fine (up to NPR 25,000), and mandatory compensation/rehabilitation for the victim. The National Penal (Code) Act, 2017 supplements with provisions on grievous hurt, causing miscarriage, and sexual offenses within marriage.
legal_document_source: Domestic Violence (Crime and Punishment) Act, 2066 (2009) & National Penal (Code) Act, 2017

text: Physical Violence by Husband Against Wife: Beating, slapping, kicking, burning, or causing any bodily injury by a husband to his wife constitutes domestic violence. The Domestic Violence Act provides protection orders, interim relief (e.g., residence rights, maintenance), and punishment: imprisonment up to 6 months and/or fine up to NPR 25,000 (Section 13). If the violence causes grievous hurt (fracture, permanent disfigurement), higher penalties apply under Penal Code Section 193 (up to 10 years imprisonment + fine). Victim can file FIR at police station or seek immediate protection from court.

text: Physical Violence by Wife Against Husband: Beating, assaulting, or causing bodily injury by a wife to her husband is equally an offense under the Domestic Violence Act (gender-neutral definition of 'domestic violence'). Punishment: imprisonment up to 6 months and/or fine up to NPR 25,000. If grievous hurt is caused, Penal Code provisions (up to 10 years imprisonment) apply. Husband can file complaint at police station or seek protection order. In practice, such cases are less frequently reported due to social stigma, but legally fully actionable.

text: Protection Orders and Immediate Relief: In any domestic violence case (husband beating wife or wife beating husband), the victim can apply for a protection order from the District Court or local judicial body. The court can issue interim orders within 24 hours, including: prohibiting the abuser from contacting the victim, evicting the abuser from the shared home, granting temporary custody of children, and ordering maintenance. Violation of protection order is punishable by imprisonment up to 6 months and/or fine NPR 25,000 (Section 14).

text: Mental and Economic Abuse: Domestic violence includes mental torture (insults, humiliation, threats) and economic abuse (denying money for household expenses, controlling finances, depriving basic needs). These are punishable under the Domestic Violence Act (imprisonment up to 6 months + fine NPR 25,000). If mental abuse leads to suicide attempt or severe psychological harm, Penal Code provisions on abetment to suicide (Section 181) or causing hurt apply (up to 5–10 years). Applies equally to husband or wife as perpetrator.

text: Sexual Violence Within Marriage: Marital rape and forced sexual acts by husband or wife are criminal offenses under the National Penal (Code) Act, 2017 (Section 219). Punishment: imprisonment 7–14 years if force/grievous hurt is used. The Domestic Violence Act also covers sexual abuse within the family. Consent is mandatory even in marriage; no spousal immunity exists. Victim (wife or husband) can file FIR; courts increasingly recognize marital rape cases, though social stigma remains a barrier.

text: Reporting, Investigation, and Support for Victims: Victims of domestic violence (whether wife or husband) can file complaint at nearest police station, Women and Children Service Center, or directly in District Court. Police must register FIR within 24 hours, provide immediate protection, and conduct medical examination if physical injury. One-Stop Crisis Management Centers (OCMC) in hospitals offer medical, legal, and counseling support. Victim can seek compensation (medical expenses, lost income, pain/suffering) and protection order. False complaints are punishable under Penal Code (Section 211).
legal_document_source: Domestic Violence (Crime and Punishment) Act, 2066, Sections 4–9 & National Penal (Code) Act, 2017

text: Short title and commencement: (1) This Act may be cited as the "National Civil (Code), 2017".  (2) It shall come into force on 17 August 2018 (first day of the  month of Bhadra of the year 2075).

Definitions: Unless the subject or the context otherwise requires, in this Act,-  5    (a)  “court” means the Supreme Court, High Court or  District Court, and this term includes a court, other  judicial body or authority authorized by law to proceed  and adjudicate any specific type of civil cases,  (b)  "law" means a law in force for the time being,  (c)  "person" means a natural person and this term includes  a legal person,  (d)  "law-suit" means a statement of claims, and this term  includes any other kind of complaint, claim,  counterclaim or equivalent petition,  (e)  “minor” means a child who has not attained eighteen  years of age,  (f)  "Local  Level"  means  the  Rural  Municipality  (Gownpalika) or Municipality,  (g)  "property" means any movable or immovable property,  (h)  "heir" means a person who is in the order of priority   for succession pursuant to Section 239.
Not to prejudice special legal provisions: Where a law in force provides a separate provision in any matter regulated by this Act,  no provision of this Act shall affect such a matter.
Principles and provisions applicable generally: The principles and provisions referred to in this Chapter shall generally be  applicable to the matters of civil law.
Ignorance of law not to be excused: The ignorance of law shall not be excused. Every one shall be presumed to have the knowledge  of law.
Act against public interest not to be carried out: No one may carry out any act in such a manner so that it may be against public  interest.
Act contrary to law to be invalid: Any act contrary to law shall be invalid.

A wrongdoer to bear liability for loss or damage: (1) A person  who causes loss or damage to another person by committing a  wrong while doing, or causing to be done any act shall bear the  liability for such loss or damage.  (2)  Every person shall himself or herself bear the  consequences of any wrongful act committed by him or her.  (3)  Except as otherwise provided for in this Act or law, the  concerned person shall bear compensation to perform the liability  referred to in sub-section (1).
Act causing nuisance to other not to be done: No person shall do, or cause to be done, any act that causes nuisance, annoyance or  damage to prestige, reputation or property of another person.
Not to enjoy benefit of wrong: No person shall be entitled to enjoy benefit accrued from his or her own wrong.

Act against interest to be invalid: Any act done against the interest of a person who is under one's own guardianship,  curatorship, subjection or influence or likely be under influence  shall be invalid.
Personality to be recognized: Every person shall recognize other person's personality.
Good neighborhood to be maintained: Every person shall maintain so good neighborhood as not to cause damage, loss to the  community or neighbors of his or her residence.

Not to be relieved from civil liability: No person shall be relieved from a civil liability under the law merely on the ground that the  proceeding of criminal offense is initiated or not initiated against  him or her.
Custom or tradition contrary to law not to be recognized: No custom or tradition contrary to law shall be recognized in the  dispensation of justice.

Applicable to foreigners as well: Except in cases where the subject, context or nature requires application of any legal provision  only to a Nepali citizen, this Act or other provisions concerning  civil law shall be equally applicable to a foreigner as well.
To be equal before law:  (1) Every citizen shall be equal before law.  (2)  No citizen shall be deprived of equal protection of law.

Discrimination not to be made: (1) No discrimination shall be made in the application of general law on grounds of origin,  religion, color, caste, race, sex, physical condition, disability,  condition of health, marital status, pregnancy, economic condition,  language, region, ideological conviction or on similar other ground.  (2)  No person shall discriminated in any public and private  place on grounds of origin, religion, color, caste, race, sex, physical  condition, disability, condition of health, marital status, pregnancy,  economic condition, language, region, ideological conviction or on  similar other ground; and no person shall, on such ground, be  prevented from using service, amenities or utilities of public use or  from entering into a public place or public religious place or from  performing religious act according to his or her will.  (3)  No person shall be discriminated on ground of sex with  regard to remuneration and social security for the same work.  (4)  In appointing any citizen to a governmental or public  office, he or she shall be appointed only on the basis of the  qualifications determined by the law. In so appointing, no citizen  shall be discriminated on grounds of origin, religion, color, caste,  race, sex, physical condition, disability, condition of health, marital  9    status,  pregnancy,  economic  condition,  language,  region,  ideological conviction or similar other ground.
